stem: A 28-year-old client with a tibia fracture reports worsening leg pain. Based on the documentation in the Orthopedic Manometry & Objective Perfusion Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: At 07:30, suspect acute compartment syndrome in a 28-year-old male with a right tibia fracture following a massive crush injury. Objective pressure check is needed.
Background: The client sustained the injury at 06:00. Initial pain was managed with analgesics, but the client now reports a pain level of 10/10, unrelieved by Fentanyl.
Assessment: The right lower leg is tense and tight to palpation. Stryker needle manometry was ordered.
Recommendation: Please prepare for emergent Stryker needle manometry to rule out compartment syndrome. Be ready to assist with potential fasciotomy based on manometry results.

tabs.title: Manometry & Perfusion Log
tabs.content:

Anterior Compartment38 mmHgCritical (> 30)

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 138/88, HR 112, RR 22, SpO2 98%. Hand/Foot is cool.

actionOptions.text: Prepare the client for an emergent fasciotomy.
Keep the extremity at the level of the heart (neutral position).
Apply a sequential compression device (SCD) to push out the fluid.
Administer STAT IV Heparin to treat the blockage.

parameterOptions.text: Intracompartmental pressure (mmHg) and Delta Pressure trends.
The 6 Ps (Pain, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia).
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose.
Presence of a positive Babinski sign.

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing Acute Compartment Syndrome (c2), objectively verified by a Stryker manometry reading of 38 mmHg in the anterior compartment and a Delta Pressure of 12 mmHg. A pressure above 30 mmHg, or a Delta Pressure less than 30 mmHg, is the standard threshold for fasciotomy. The priority is preparing the client for an emergent fasciotomy (a1) to release the pressure and prevent muscle necrosis. Elevating the extremity to heart level (a2) helps optimize arterial inflow while minimizing venous congestion. Monitoring should focus on trends in intracompartmental pressure and Delta Pressure (p1), as well as the classic clinical signs known as the 6 Ps (p2).
clinicalPearls: Compartment pressure > 30 mmHg is the classic indicator that surgery is necessary.
Never apply ice to a limb with compartment syndrome; it causes vasoconstriction and accelerates tissue death.
Pulselessness is a LATE sign of compartment syndrome; waiting for it indicates likely limb loss.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a pressure of 38 is 'normal' because the BP is 138/88.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Compartment pressure is the INTERNAL pressure within the muscle compartment. Normal pressure is close to zero. Pressures above 30 mmHg compromise capillary perfusion, leading to ischemia and necrosis.
